titleStmt.title: GLORY DAYS
a new musical by Nick Blaemire & James Gardiner

publicationStmt.distributor: Please address inquiries to: William Craver Paradigm New York 360 Park Avenue South, 16th Floor New York, New York 10010 wcraver@paradigmagency.com (212) 897-6400

front.docAuthor: Music and Lyrics by Nick Blaemire

body.stage: (A night in May. A high school football field. WILLIAM LEVINSON, 18, enters wearing a backpack and carrying a small notebook. He walks out to the center of the field)

lg.l: LOOK AT THIS FIELD
LOOK AT THIS PERFECT FIELD
THE POSSIBILITIES ARE ENDLESS HERE
JUST WHITE LINES
NO BOUNDARIES TO HOLD US HERE
EXCEPT FOR TIME
AND SO MUCH HISTORY
REMEMBER WHAT HAS HAPPENED HERE
ALL THE STORIES
GAMES THAT HAVE BEEN WON
AND FRIENDS HAVING FUN
COMING BACK FOR ONE PERFECT NIGHT
RIGHT HERE

body.stage: (WILL sets his backpack down on the player's bench. He opens his notebook and begins to read)

lg.l: THIS IS THE STORY OF FOUR BEST FRIENDS
WHEN WE'RE IN ONE PLACE THE NIGHT NEVER ENDS
WE TALK ABOUT THINGS THAT MATTER, AND THEN
IN THE SAME BREATH ACT LIKE WE'RE TEN
AND THEN DO IT ALL OVER AGAIN
WE'RE FROM - JUST IMAGINE THIS KIND OF TOWN
WHERE THE POPULAR CLIQUE KEEPS YOU DOWN
IF YOU CAN'T PUT ON PADS AND MAKE CAVEMAN SOUNDS
AS YOU KNOCK SMALLER KIDS THAN YOU TO THE GROUND
DOESN'T THAT SOUND FUN TO BE AROUND?
WE WERE NEVER BIG ENOUGH OR FAST ENOUGH
TO KEEP UP WITH ALL OF THEM
BUT WE WERE ALWAYS SMART ENOUGH AND QUICK ENOUGH
TO KNOW WE'D BE BETTER IN THE END
THAN THE SENIORS FROM THE FOOTBALL TEAM
WHO WOULDN'T LET US PLAY
WE COULDN'T CATCH OR RUN AS FAST
SO THEY TOLD US WE WERE GAY
THEY TRIED TO MAKE US WORSHIP THEM
BUT WE LIKED THINGS OUR WAY
JUST ME AND MY THREE BEST FRIENDS

body.stage: (WILL begins flipping through the pages of his notebook)

lg.l: SKIP IS THE CYNIC AND JACK'S THE VOICE OF REASON
AND ANDY'S THE REASON THAT SKIP IS A CYNIC
WE'RE BICKERING BROTHERS, IT'S SICK
IT'S LIKE IF OIL AND WATER COULD MIX
THERE'S SOMETHING ABOUT US THAT JUST CLICKS
CUZ I AM THE GLUE THAT HOLDS US TOGETHER
OBSERVER, INVENTOR, AND SOLE DOCUMENTOR
CONSTANTLY WATCHING, THE CONSTANT INCENTIVE
TO KEEP MOVING FORWARD, AND ALWAYS REMEMBER
WHERE WE STARTED FROM, AND HOW FAR WE'VE COME
SINCE THE DAYS WHEN WE HAD NO ONE
BUT WHEN WE FORMED THIS PERFECT UNION
A NEW ERA HAD BEGUN
WE GET THIS LIFE SO DIFFERENTLY
THEN ANYONE OUR AGE CHOOSES TO SEE
ME AND MY THREE BEST FRIENDS
YOUR BEST FRIENDS OPEN UP YOUR MIND
TO PARTS OF YOU YOU COULDN'T FIND
THEY SAVED MY LIFE FRESHMAN YEAR
AND I THANK THEM EVERY DAY RIGHT HERE
WE'VE BEEN AWAY FOR WAY TOO LONG
AND ALL THAT TIME ALONE FELT WRONG
CAUSE WE BELONG RIGHT HERE
BUT WE'RE COMING BACK TONIGHT
TO REMEMBER WHAT WE WERE LIKE
AND PICK UP RIGHT WHERE WE LET GO
ALMOST A YEAR AGO
I KNOW THIS STORY SO WELL
AND IT IS MINE TO TELL
BECAUSE IT IS HAPPENING...TO ME
YEA ME AND MY THREE
ME AND MY THREE
ME AND MY THREE
BEST FRIENDS

body.stage: (WILL slams his notebook shut and tosses it under the bench)

sp.speaker: WILL
sp.p: It's so good to see you.

sp.speaker: SKIP
sp.p: You too. (beat) Where are the other fools? I thought you said midnight.

sp.speaker: WILL
sp.p: (exasperated) I know... I probably should have told them 9. (beat) What's up with your hair?

sp.speaker: SKIP
sp.p: You like? I'm just letting nature do its thing.

sp.speaker: SKIP
sp.p: Oh, you wanna start already? Cause we can go Tubs Tubs!

sp.speaker: SKIP
sp.p: Wanna go? Let's go! Who's a girl now? Huh? Who's a girl now Tub Tubs? Wanna cry?

sp.speaker: WILL
sp.p: I'm joking! No. Okay, okay! No, no, no. I'm sorry. Cut it out.

sp.speaker: WILL
sp.p: HEY, look, if you don't stop I'm not gonna tell you what we're doing tonight!

sp.speaker: SKIP
sp.p: (stops) What we're doing? I thought this was it.

sp.speaker: WILL
sp.p: Nope. I've got a plan. Tell me -

lg.l: ARE YOU READY FOR TONIGHT?
ARE YOU READY TO MAKE HISTORY?
RIGHT HERE ON THIS FOOTBALL FIELD
YOU AND ME
AND TWO OTHER GUYS
WHO COULD SHOW UP AT ANY TIME
WHEN EVER THEY DO GET HERE, I'M
HOPING YOU'RE READY

sp.speaker: WILL
sp.p: (coyly) Cause... I don't know if I trust you.

lg.l: WHEN THE TIMING IS RIGHT
WE ALL WILL BE HERE FINALLY
AND WHEN WE ARE, YOU'LL FINALLY SEE
"WHAT THIS HIGH SCHOOL MEANS TO ME"
HOW 'BOUT A HINT?
HOW 'BOUT WE WAIT FOR ALL THE GUYS
I'LL ACT LIKE I'M STILL SURPRISED!
FINE. DO YOU LIKE WATER RIDES?
Are we going to Sea World?

sp.speaker: SKIP
sp.p: I hate you. (beat) Is it something -?

lg.l: DON'T EVEN TRY TO GUESS
YOU WONT BE ABLE TO
CAUSE WHAT WE'RE GONNA DO
IS GONNA DUMBFOUND EVEN YOU

body.stage: (ANDY SCOTT, 19, and JACK MOYER, 19, enter bickering.)

sp.speaker: ANDY
sp.p: Oh pleeease dude, Batman is so much cooler. He's got all those gadgets and shit-

sp.speaker: JACK
sp.p: So!? Superman could pick up an entire planet and drop it on Batman.

sp.speaker: ANDY
sp.p: Yeah, but can he stop a Batarang?

sp.speaker: JACK
sp.p: He can travel at the speed of light, Andy. You don't think he can get away from a Batarang?

sp.speaker: ANDY
sp.p: Will, help me out here. Batman verse Superman. Who wins?

body.stage: (WILL and JACK hug and continue their own conversation)

sp.speaker: SKIP
sp.p: Yeah, nice to see you too.

body.stage: (ANDY hugs SKIP. Without missing a beat, ANDY tries to get SKIP's opinion on the whole Batman vs. Superman debate.)

lg.l: ARE YOU READY FOR TONIGHT?
CAN YOU BELIEVE WE'RE BACK OUT HERE?
IT HAS BEEN THE LONGEST YEAR!
I GOTTA SAY IT'S PRETTY WEIRD
HOW WAS LIFE AT SCHOOL?
PROBABLY THE SAME AS YOU
THERE IS NO WAY THAT'S TRUE UNLESS YOU ROOMED WITH ANDY TOO.
HOW THE HELL COULD YOU THINK THAT BATMAN
WOULD LOSE A BATTLE TO A GUY IN TIGHTS?
HAVEN'T YOU SEEN THE GAY RED UNDIES
HE WEARS OUTSIDE OF HIS PANTS?
I DON'T EVEN KNOW WHY YOU'D EVER BEGIN
TO ARGUE WITH ME, WHEN YOU KNOW YOU'LL NEVER WIN
BATMAN IS HUMAN AND SUPERMAN'S NOT
SO WHO'S GONNA DIE IF ONE OF THEM GETS SHOT?
Sooo... ARE WE READY FOR TONIGHT?
WHAT THE HELL IS GOING ON?
HAVE I EVER STEERED YOU WRONG?
I DUNNO. IT'S BEEN SO LONG.
JUST GET READY FOR TONIGHT
AND WHAT A NIGHT IT'S GONNA BE
YOU AND YOU AND YOU AND ME
FINALLY...
BACK TOGETHER
I'VE MISSED YOU GUYS
YOU ONLY LIKE SUPERMAN CAUSE HE FLIES
NOW ARE YOU READY FOR
READY
FOR TONIGHT
RIGHT
HERE!!

sp.speaker: WILL
sp.p: What took you guys so long?

sp.speaker: JACK
sp.p: Ask slobbers over here, I was waiting outside his house for like 10 minutes!

sp.speaker: ANDY
sp.p: I said I was sorry! I'm sorry!

sp.speaker: JACK
sp.p: He was passed out in the living room watching Ella Enchanted.

sp.speaker: ANDY
sp.p: Whatever man! My sister was watching it.

sp.speaker: SKIP
sp.p: That's good. (beat) Does she still ask about me?

sp.speaker: ANDY
sp.p: I'm gonna punch you in the face -

sp.speaker: SKIP
sp.p: Hey now, there's no need to get all huffy...it's not my fault your sister's bangin'!

sp.speaker: JACK
sp.p: Hey, whatever floats your boat, right?

sp.speaker: ANDY
sp.p: (to JACK)My sister is not allowed to float anyone's boat!

body.stage: (ANDY chases SKIP and JACK around the field)

sp.speaker: SKIP
sp.p: What? Take it as a compliment. You've got good genes!

sp.speaker: WILL
sp.p: All right guys! Come on! Hey! HEY!

body.stage: (WILL throws his arms around ANDY to hold him back. Andy continues to struggle)
body.p: (to ANDY)Chill! Look, we've got important business to take care of -
body.stage: (ANDY stops struggling and WILL releases him.

sp.speaker: ANDY
sp.p: I can see that! (to WILL) What's it for?

body.stage: (ANDY takes a look at the paper. Clears his throat and reads)

sp.speaker: ANDY
sp.p: (reading) "Come one, come all to the Fighting Beavers Annual Alumni Football Game." What!? FIGHTING Beavers? When did they change that shit!

sp.speaker: WILL
sp.p: Apparently they didn't think the beaver was intimidating enough on its own.

sp.speaker: ANDY
sp.p: But that makes no sense. Beavers aren't violent. They're gentle woodland creatures.

sp.speaker: ANDY
sp.p: Okay! (reading) "On Saturday May 20th watch our very own Fighting Beavers" ... (aside)mmmGAY! ... "take on the Varsity Alumni in what promises to be a real treat. All Alumni are invited to attend."

sp.speaker: SKIP
sp.p: Wow, you read that really well! You didn't stutter or anything.

sp.speaker: ANDY
sp.p: Shut up! (to WILL) What the hell is this?

body.stage: (WILL takes the paper from ANDY and walks back towards the player's bench)
(WILL steps up on the player's bench as if it were his own personal soapbox)

sp.speaker: WILL
sp.p: Do you guys realize what this means? Tomorrow afternoon. Right here. We're gonna have... (pointing to Andy) can I get a drum roll please?
sp.stage: (ANDY obliges, easily amused by his own improvised drum roll. His drum roll slows as the names start to land)
sp.p: Matt Hoffman, Chris Peterson, Eric Spencer, Danny Barwick -

sp.speaker: WILL
sp.p: Yes shit! The whole lot of em. And at exactly 1:30, while they're lining up for the opening kick, they're going to witness... no scratch that... EXPERIENCE a miracle. You see that box?

body.stage: (WILL points to a small weather box situated near the players bench)

sp.speaker: WILL
sp.p: That box contains something truly magical.

sp.speaker: WILL
sp.p: No. Better. Inside that box is the timer to the school's brand new... state of the art... sprinkler system. (reaches into his pocket and pulls out a key) And this, my friends, is the key.

sp.speaker: ANDY
sp.p: (amazed. To WILL) We're gonna soak the bastards!

sp.speaker: WILL
sp.p: Let's just call it retribution. This is for every time we were made fun of. For every time we were walked over or treated like shit. This is karma at its finest boys!

sp.speaker: ANDY
sp.p: Blown! My mind is officially blown.

sp.speaker: WILL
sp.p: We've waited for this moment for five years and tomorrow it's on. All we have to do is reset the timer.

sp.speaker: ANDY
sp.p: (extends his hand to WILL) Well done sir!

sp.speaker: ANDY
sp.p: I take back every time I ever called you queer. (beat) For the next five minutes.

sp.speaker: JACK
sp.p: Are you gonna tell us who or not?

sp.speaker: WILL
sp.p: (to SKIP, referencing ANDY) Exactly why I didn't want to tell you!

sp.speaker: ANDY
sp.p: You don't remember PAT!? Sophomore last year, redhead? She's the janitor's niece. Kinda ... thick?

sp.speaker: JACK
sp.p: You did just call her Fat Pat.

sp.speaker: SKIP
sp.p: (to WILL) Wait, is this the girl who asked you to homecoming, but you said no for religious reasons?

sp.speaker: SKIP
sp.p: Why'd she give it to you?

sp.speaker: WILL
sp.p: (a slight hesitation) Cause she was being nice.

sp.speaker: ANDY
sp.p: (joking) Yeah right! What'd you do, take her out on a date?

sp.speaker: WILL
sp.p: (caught off guard) No, it wasn't a - (stops mid sentence. Catches himself)

sp.speaker: ANDY
sp.p: Oh sweet Lord Jesus NO! (beat) You DID!

sp.speaker: WILL
sp.p: No I - No. (pause) It wasn't a date.

sp.speaker: ANDY
sp.p: (hardly controlling himself) Then what was it?

sp.speaker: WILL
sp.p: We just went out to eat.

sp.speaker: ANDY
sp.p: To EAT!? That's an operation. Where'd you take her? Arby's? No wait! No no wait I got it - it's coming to me - where would you take her so no one would see you AND your jew ass could feed her for cheap.... Denny's!

sp.speaker: ANDY
sp.p: (laughing hysterically) Yes!!! I knew it! What'd she get? I have to know.

sp.speaker: ANDY
sp.p: A steak, or three? Some cheeseburgers? Maybe a nice little Chocolate Brownie Fudge Delight with some extra fixins?

sp.speaker: ANDY
sp.p: Oh we are beyond sprinkles! You KNOW that girl can throw down! We're talking marshmallows, butter scotch, peanuts, candy corn, pop corn... maybe some real corn -

sp.speaker: ANDY
sp.p: Hot fudge, a couple bananas for potassium -

sp.speaker: WILL
sp.p: You're a real jerk, you know that?

sp.speaker: ANDY
sp.p: Ah come on man. I'm just playing! Look, I'm seriously proud of you! She's a catch.

sp.speaker: WILL
sp.p: She's not a catch and you know it!

sp.speaker: WILL
sp.p: I didn't say that. You're the one calling her fat!

sp.speaker: ANDY
sp.p: All I'm saying is she's a sure thing. (putting his arm around WILL) And Will, buddy, you need to start taking advantage of these opportunities. Cause let's be honest, you didn't really get any this year.

sp.speaker: WILL
sp.p: (pushing ANDY away) Just cuz I didn't want any of the diseased skanks that you and your frat brothers hooked up with doesn't mean I didn't get any.

sp.speaker: ANDY
sp.p: What are you talking about? Those girls were prime real estate!

sp.speaker: SKIP
sp.p: Woah, woah, woah. I'm sorry. You joined a frat?

sp.speaker: ANDY
sp.p: (proudly) Hells yeah manio! Delta Kai Epsilon! Deke Men - Class of 2010 baby!

sp.speaker: WILL
sp.p: I know. Of all things. (points to ANDY) HUGE hypocrite!

sp.speaker: WILL
sp.p: Cause it goes against everything we stand for.

sp.speaker: JACK
sp.p: Isn't that kinda like buying your friends?

sp.speaker: ANDY
sp.p: (offended) No! It's about a brotherhood. A fellowship! A bond!

sp.speaker: ANDY
sp.p: Whatever man, all I know is I was getting some high quality poon this year while you were sitting alone in your room jerkin the gherkin!

sp.speaker: ANDY
sp.p: Oh really? Why don't you tell Jack and Skip how many girls you boofed?

sp.speaker: ANDY
sp.p: Well I'll tell you! The answer is zero. None! Nada! He couldn't get a single girl to touch his little Jewish ding-a-ling.

sp.speaker: SKIP
sp.p: Yeah, I never would have thought -

sp.speaker: ANDY
sp.p: Bullshit!! (to SKIP and JACK) He's lying!

sp.speaker: ANDY
sp.p: (to SKIP and JACK) I've been with him the whole year. He hasn't even talked to 15 girls.

sp.speaker: WILL
sp.p: You don't have to talk to 'em when you're doing it.

lg.l: D'YOU EVER WONDER WHERE THE FEMALES GO
WHEN THERE'S NO ONE AT THE BAR AND IT'S LONELY ON THE DANCE FLOOR
TOO BAD FOR YOU BECAUSE THEY'RE HERE WITH ME
WAITING IN LINE UNTIL WE MAMBO HORIZONTALLY
D'YOU EVER WONDER WHERE HE GETS THIS SHIT
OR IF ANY OF THE SKANKS THAT HE BANGS BELIEVE A WORD OF IT?
HE ISN'T ANYBODY'S MR. RIGHT
I'M THE ONE THE LADIES WANT FOR MORE THAN JUST A NIGHT
DON'T LISTEN TO A WORD HE SAYS
HE HASN'T BEEN KISSED SINCE TRUTH OR DARE
HOW DO YOU KNOW THAT'S TRUE
WHEN IM WITH GIRLS I DON'T THINK YOU'RE THERE
I SAY WHAT THEY WANNA HEAR
AND YOU DON'T KNOW CUZ YOU DON'T CARE
IVE GOT GIRLS BY THE BALLS
IVE FIGURED EM OUT AND GOT EM UP AGAINST THE WALL
YOU'VE GOT NOTHING AT ALL
YOU'RE MAKING THIS UP!
YOU'D HAVE TO HIDE IN A WOMEN'S BATHROOM STALL

body.l: TO GET A GIRL NEAR YOUR BALLS

sp.speaker: ANDY
sp.p: Don't lie Will, it makes you look bad.

sp.speaker: WILL
sp.p: Hey, I'm not saying I'm the best looking guy around. I never used to get any, but things change, Andy. Things change.

lg.l: IN HIGH SCHOOL, GIRLS WERE OUT OF MY LEAGUE AND I KNEW IT
ONE AWKWARD GLANCE OR THEY'D SEE ME DANCE AND I BLEW IT

sp.speaker: SKIP
sp.p: Well you've always got Fat Pat...

lg.l: BUT COLLEGE GIRLS ARE MUCH MORE MY STYLE
CUZ THEY'RE JEWISH
ALL THEY DO IS TURN YOU AND YOUR JEW BALLS BLUISH
IT'S TOO BAD YOU'RE AN IDIOT
YOU MIGHT GET SOME IF YOU GOT TO CLASS

sp.speaker: ANDY

lg.l: I NEVER NEEDED IT
I KNOW MY SHIT AND CAN STILL KICK YOUR ASS
IVE GOT GIRLS BY THE BALLS
IM GETTING EM HOT CAUSE THEY LIKE IT WHEN THEY'RE GUYS ARE TALL

sp.p: If you know what I mean... (laughs)

lg.l: YOU'VE GOT SOME KIND OF GALL
BUT NO KIND OF BRAIN
THOSE STEROIDS YOU'RE ON MAKE YOUR VITAL ORGANS SMALL
LIKE THE ONE NEXT TO YOUR BALLS
OHHH! (laughs)
WHO DO YOU THINK YOU ARE?
THE DORK WHO'S GONE AND RAISED THE BAR
YOU WISH YOU HAD MY LOOKS
AND YOU WISH YOU COULD READ A BOOK
YOU ARE THE OPPOSITE OF ME
IM MORE THAN HAPPY TO AGREE

sp.speaker: WILL
sp.p: If you've hooked up with so many girls, then why are you always jacking off?

sp.speaker: ANDY
sp.p: Cause your Mom is constantly on my mind.

body.stage: (WILL manages to pin ANDY to the ground)

sp.speaker: ANDY
sp.p: That's funny- this is your Mom's favorite position too.

body.stage: (SKIP pulls WILL off of ANDY. JACK helps ANDY off the ground)

sp.speaker: JACK
sp.p: You guys haven't changed a bit.

sp.speaker: ANDY
sp.p: You're right, Will's still a lying sack of shit!

sp.speaker: WILL
sp.p: At least I have a sack! Pussy.

body.stage: (ANDY rushes at WILL. SKIP holds him back. JACK grabs WILL)

sp.speaker: SKIP
sp.p: Knock it off. Man, you guys can't fight for shit.

sp.speaker: JACK
sp.p: Come on! Don't you two want nice, sane things? Like love?

lg.l: OF COURSE WE WANT TO BE IN LOVE
AND WE'RE LOOKING FOR ROMANCE
BUT TIL WE FIND THAT LONESOME DOVE
WE'LL JUST GET INTO THEIR PAAAAANTS!!

body.stage: (ANDY and WILL sing into the night)

lg.l: WE'VE GOT GIRLS BY THE BALLS
THEY'RE LOOKIN FOR LOVE BUT THAT'S NOT WHAT WE'RE MAKIN AT ALL
WE'VE GOT GIRLS BY THE BALLS AND WE'RE HOLDIN ON
IT'S TIME FOR EVERY GIRL TO BE GRABBED
BY THE BALLS!
HOW DO YOU WIN A PLAYOFF RACE?
BY THE BALLS!
AND WHERE DO WE LIKE A PRETTY GIRL'S FACE?
BY THE BALLS!
AND WHERE DO I HAVE YOUR MOM!
BY THE - Oh fuck you Andy!
YEAAAAAAAAAAAA!
Well, I'm glad to see you guys have grown up.

sp.speaker: JACK
sp.p: I can't believe you two lived in the same room for a whole year.

sp.speaker: WILL
sp.p: It was hard sometimes. (points to ANDY) He never showers.

sp.speaker: ANDY
sp.p: Whatever, I was a great roommate.

sp.speaker: JACK
sp.p: I wouldn't want to live with you.

sp.speaker: ANDY
sp.p: Why!? (puts his hand on JACK) We could be bunk buddies! (JACK shrugs him off)

sp.speaker: WILL
sp.p: Can you imagine if the four of us had all lived together? I mean what if we had all actually gone to the same school?

sp.speaker: ANDY
sp.p: That would've been tight! The four of us in a suite, trading bitches like Pokemon cards!

sp.speaker: WILL
sp.p: I mean, just think of all the stuff we could've pulled on a college campus.

sp.speaker: SKIP
sp.p: You mean stupid pranks like this one?

sp.speaker: WILL
sp.p: What are you talking about? This is going to be epic! We're going to go down in history for this.

sp.speaker: SKIP
sp.p: With who? No one's even gonna know we did it!

body.stage: (WILL takes the key and walks over to the box)

sp.speaker: ANDY
sp.p: (to SKIP) What is your problem, Debbie Downer?

sp.speaker: ANDY
sp.p: You. Anytime there's any risk involved you turn into little miss Negative Nancy!

sp.speaker: ANDY
sp.p: Yes you do! Seriously, I thought you were gonna wet yourself that time we took out your Dad's Jeep.

sp.speaker: ANDY
sp.p: Yeah, but you were sweatin' beads the whole time. "I dunno guys, maybe we should abort..."

sp.speaker: JACK
sp.p: To be fair, his dad is pretty frightening.

sp.speaker: SKIP
sp.p: My dad's in the military, jackass!

sp.speaker: ANDY
sp.p: Yeah, but you're not! Nobody said you had to speak douchebag!

sp.speaker: WILL
sp.p: Andy, will you shut up for a second!

lg.l: ARE WE READY FOR TONIGHT?
AREN'T WE ALREADY HERE?
DID ANYBODY GET THE BEER?
WE'LL DRINK IT WHEN WE'RE IN THE CLEAR
SO GET READY FOR TONIGHT
AND WHAT A NIGHT ITS GONNA BE
YOU AND YOU AND YOU AND ME

body.stage: (The boys move over to the box)

lg.l: FINALLY...

sp.speaker: ANDY
sp.p: Get outta the way! You don't know how to turn a friggin key.

body.stage: (ANDY pushes WILL out of the way)
body.p: Here. See you gotta turn it to the left you dil-
body.stage: (ANDY tries to turn the key, but the lock won't budge)
body.p: You gotta turn it - to the -
body.stage: (ANDY tries again, but the lock still won't budge)

sp.speaker: ANDY
sp.p: (to WILL) You got the wrong key!

sp.speaker: WILL
sp.p: I got the wrong key!? This is what she gave me.

sp.speaker: ANDY
sp.p: You got scammed by a plus sized hooker!

sp.speaker: WILL
sp.p: She probably just got em mixed up.

sp.speaker: ANDY
sp.p: Why the hell would I call her? She's your girlfriend!

sp.speaker: ANDY
sp.p: Look, stop being a pussy. (ANDY takes out his phone) If she got em mixed up then she can bring over the right one-

sp.speaker: WILL
sp.p: No, its gonna give her the wrong idea.

body.stage: (WILL tosses the phone back to ANDY)

sp.speaker: ANDY
sp.p: Just tell her to put down the pork chops and get over here-

body.stage: (WILL tosses the phone back to ANDY)

sp.speaker: ANDY
sp.p: Well I guess we can't do the prank then.

body.stage: (WILL tosses the phone to ANDY. SKIP catches it)

sp.speaker: SKIP
sp.p: Jesus, you guys are like a pair of three year olds. who cares!?

sp.speaker: WILL
sp.p: What do you mean who cares?

sp.speaker: ANDY
sp.p: What are we supposed to do now?

sp.speaker: SKIP
sp.p: Why don't we try hanging out for a change? You ever think of that?

sp.speaker: SKIP
sp.p: No, this is not hanging out. You guys wanna play Inspector Gadget or whatever, but I'd rather just sit here and drink some beers. Why do we have to DO something to make the night memorable? I haven't seen you guys in almost a year. We're finally together in the same place. Isn't that enough?

sp.speaker: SKIP
sp.p: Think about it. We don't have to associate ourselves with this place ever again, so why do you wanna come back and pull some stupid prank? We're past that.

sp.speaker: JACK
sp.p: (to WILL) I'm with him on this one, sorry.

sp.speaker: WILL
sp.p: Guys! Andy? Help me out here.

sp.speaker: ANDY
sp.p: I mean, yeah, I still think it'd be funny as shit.

sp.speaker: WILL
sp.p: And it sends a message. (the boys are unconvinced) It does!

sp.speaker: SKIP
sp.p: Oh that makes a ton of sense. (beat) Will. You really think they're gonna start respecting us for setting off sprinklers during their little charity football game?

sp.speaker: WILL
sp.p: It's not about that - it's.... (beat) Come on, don't you think they deserve it!

sp.speaker: JACK
sp.p: Will it was five years ago!

sp.speaker: WILL
sp.p: So!? It still happened! And all because we didn't make their precious little team -

sp.speaker: WILL
sp.p: They're the reason that we're friends. So why not, you know, celebrate that by giving them the fuck you that they deserve?

sp.speaker: SKIP
sp.p: But Will, they're not gonna care. They never did, so why would they start now?

sp.speaker: WILL
sp.p: Then maybe, it's not about them! Maybe it's about us!

lg.l: WHEN YOU WERE YOUNG
DIDN'T YOU HAVE DREAMS THAT YOU LET GO OF
CUZ SOMEBODY TOLD YOU THAT YOU WEREN'T ALLOWED TO DREAM
THE WAY YOU DO
JUST CUZ YOU WERE DIFFERENT
LIKE
WHEN I WAS 12
I BOUGHT MYSELF SOME LA LIGHTS
REMEMBER, THOSE SHOES THAT YOU COULD SEE AT NIGHT
CUZ BRIAN NOONAN RULED AND HE WORE THEM TO SCHOOL
AND I HATED HIM
BUT I WANTED TO BE COOL
OR
IN 7TH GRADE
I STARTED SAYING "CHILLIN BRO"
EVEN THOUGH IT WASN'T COLD
CAUSE ERIC SPENCER SAID EVERYONE ELSE KNEW WHAT IT MEANT
AND IF I DIDN'T
I'D LOOK LIKE A TOOL
THAT'S WHAT I USED TO THINK
RIGHT WHEN I WAS ON THE BRINK
OF BEING JUST ANOTHER KINK IN THEIR SOCIAL REGIME
BUT MY LIFE GOT TURNED AROUND
WHEN I FOUND I GOT CUT FROM THEIR FOOTBALL TEAM
RIGHT HERE WAS THE FIRST TIME I FELT HOME
WITH NO FEAR OF MY LIFE SPENT ALL ALONE
IT WAS CLEAR UNDER THESE ELECTRIC STARS
THAT NO MATTER WHAT THEY SAW FROM OVER THERE
THIS FIELD WAS OURS
RIGHT HERE

sp.speaker: WILL
sp.p: Come on man, you used to love this stuff.

sp.speaker: SKIP
sp.p: Used to! I'd like to think I've changed a little since I left this place.

sp.speaker: WILL
sp.p: No, this place made us who we are!

lg.l: YOU WISH
YOU'D NEVER CHANGE
AND YOU'D ALWAYS BE IN THAT SAME EPIC MOMENT
BUT YOU MOVED AWAY
AND YOU CAN PRAY THAT THEY'LL STAY
BUT THE GOOD OLD DAYS SAY GOODBYE
AND SADLY, YOU ARE DIFFERENT
NO! WE ARE STILL YOUNG
AND THOUGH YOU MAY HAVE TRIED TO RID OUR LIVES
OF THE COOL PEOPLE'S BULLSHIT
THE BRUISES TO PROVE THAT IT STUNG ARE STILL HERE
CAUSE WE'RE STILL DIFFERENT
OH PLEASE, LET'S LET THIS BE
CUZ BOTH OF YOU ARE WRONG RIGHT NOW
WE ALL CHANGE AND AREN'T SURE HOW
BUT I DON'T CARE WHAT IT TOOK TO GET ME TO HERE FROM THERE
I MAY BE DIFFERENT
BUT IM STILL ME I SWEAR
YOU ARE RIGHT, BUT SO AM I
WE CAN CHANGE, BUT CAN'T DENY
WE'LL ALWAYS BE THE GUYS WE WERE WHEN WE MET
AND BACK WHEN YOU BEGAN IT
YOU DIDN'T PLAN IT
BUT YOU CANT FORGET
RIGHT HERE WAS THE FIRST PLACE YOU FELT HOME
WITH NO FEAR OF A LIFE SPENT ALL ALONE
CUZ ITS CLEAR UNDER THESE ELECTRIC STARS, THAT
NO MATTER WHAT YOU SEE FROM OVER THERE
THIS IS OURS
HERE WAS THE FIRST PLACE I FELT HOME
WITH NO FEAR OF MY LIFE SPENT ALL ALONE
CUZ ITS CLEAR UNDER THESE ELECTRIC STARS
IT ONLY MATTERS WHAT YOU SEE
RIGHT HERE
IS A BETTER PLACE THAN HOME
CUZ ITS CLEAR THAT WE'LL NEVER BE ALONE
AND THIS YEAR UNDER THESE ELECTRIC STARS
EVERYONE WILL SEE FROM OVER THERE
THAT WE ARE
RIGHT HERE

sp.speaker: WILL
sp.p: So... are we doing this or what?

sp.speaker: SKIP
sp.p: But how are we getting into this box?

body.stage: (Silence. ANDY, JACK, and SKIP look at WILL)
(WILL takes out his phone and dials)

sp.speaker: ANDY
sp.p: That's my boy. Take one for the team!

sp.speaker: WILL
sp.p: I'm always taking one for the team. (into the phone) Hi, Patty?

body.stage: (Throughout WILL's phone call the boys do everything they can to distract him. Sexual sounds, etc.)

sp.speaker: WILL
sp.p: (glares at SKIP) It's Will! Hi. I'm fine. Listen, I'm calling because there seems to have been a bit of a mix up. The key that you gave me doesn't work. Yeah, nope. So I was just wondering if there was any possibility - (beat) Oh, really!? No, that would be amazing! Thank you. (beat) Uh... Friday?

sp.speaker: ANDY
sp.p: (giving it to Friday and hard) Oh yeah, Friday!

sp.speaker: WILL
sp.p: Umm... I'm actually kinda busy then... (looking to the guys for help)

sp.speaker: WILL
sp.p:
(looking to the guys for help) I just -I got in a car accident yesterday, so... I'm injured. Injured bad.
(SKIP, ANDY and JACK begin imitating sirens, screaming children, etc)
Yea I'll be okay, just broke a few bones. Sure. Yeah just give me a call back okay. Great! Thanks!

sp.speaker: WILL
sp.p: She's babysitting right now, so she's going to look and see what she can find. She said she'd call me back.

sp.speaker: JACK
sp.p: I feel like we should have brought a board game or something.

sp.speaker: JACK
sp.p: I was thinking more along the lines of like Monopoly.

sp.speaker: ANDY
sp.p: What is that supposed to mean?

sp.speaker: SKIP
sp.p: You're just not a Monopoly kinda guy.

sp.speaker: SKIP
sp.p: No, I think it's more that you don't get it.

sp.speaker: SKIP
sp.p: No....Monopoly requires a certain level of mathematical skill that I don't think you've acquired. You know, adding and subtracting. The ability to understand numbers. It's hard.

sp.speaker: ANDY
sp.p: Jenga has that! You have to add and subtract blocks. (long beat) Okay, that was a stretch.

sp.speaker: JACK
sp.p: My roommate started a board game club in our dorm room this year. Didn't even ask.

sp.speaker: SKIP
sp.p: Ohhh Lord. I can only imagine the people who wanted to join that club.

sp.speaker: JACK
sp.p: Actually there were only five kids who kept coming back, but Jesus Christ they were annoying. They called themselves "the Clue Crew."

sp.speaker: ANDY
sp.p: That's freakin weird dude. Your roommate sounds worse then Will.

sp.speaker: JACK
sp.p: He was fine. I only had to put up with him for a little while.

sp.speaker: ANDY
sp.p: Cause this kid on our floor got kicked out for smoking weed in his room. (to WILL) Remember Stevey?

sp.speaker: ANDY
sp.p: Smart kid too ... he tried to create this like ventilation system out his window so the RA couldn't smell it. But somebody saw the smoke outside and called the fire department. Now he goes to community college. Fuckin' sucks.

sp.speaker: WILL
sp.p: Then why did you only put up with him for a little while?

sp.speaker: JACK
sp.p: I didn't see him as much.

sp.speaker: JACK
sp.p: Well... (pause) I don't know. Ok. Actually I left before the semester ended. So....

sp.speaker: ANDY
sp.p: Woah, woah, woah. Hold the phone... what ?

sp.speaker: JACK
sp.p: I don't know. It wasn't a big deal.

sp.speaker: ANDY
sp.p: Are you shitting me?! That's huge!

sp.speaker: JACK
sp.p: A little over a month... I got back like three weeks ago.

sp.speaker: WILL
sp.p: Wait...you've been home for three weeks? Why didn't you call us? (referencing ANDY too) We've been here.

sp.speaker: WILL
sp.p: I thought you were still at school. Did you not want us to know you were back?

sp.speaker: JACK
sp.p: No Will, I wasn't trying to keep anything from you. I just needed some time alone.

sp.speaker: ANDY
sp.p: Well, I don't care, I wanna know everything! Where'd you go? What'd you do? Who'd ya bang? Tell me everything!

lg.l:
SO I TOOK A MONTH OFF FROM SCHOOL
AND DECIDED TO GO ON A TRIP
I PACKED MY BAGS AND KISSED MY MOM GOODBYE

sp.speaker: ANDY
sp.p: You kissed your Mom Dude? Gross...

lg.l: AND I GOT INTO MY CAR
WHAT A LOUSY PIECE OF SHIT
BUT I DIDN'T CARE
I JUST NEEDED TO TRY
AND GO DRIVING DOWN THE COAST
IN THE NICE DAYS OR THE RAIN
I WORE THE SAME CLOTHES AND GOT FOOD ON THE GO
I TORE AROUND THOSE CURVES
JUST SPEEDING THROUGH THE PLAINS
SOMETIMES I WENT SO FAST I WANTED TO EXPLODE
CAUSE IT WAS JUST ME
AND THE OPEN ROAD
I STOPPED AT ALL THE PARKS
AND SLEPT UNDER THE SKY
AND WHEN I WOKE I DROVE THE REST OF THE DAY
I TOOK SHORTCUTS THROUGH PEOPLES' YARDS
AND RAN MY GAS TANK CLOSE TO DRY
AND WHEN I SPED BY COPS I KNEW JUST WHAT TO SAY
AFTER THE FOURTEENTH TIME
WHEN I WAS DRIVING THROUGH THE EAST
WITH THE WINDOWS ROLLED DOWN LOW
THERE WAS SO MUCH AIR THAT I COULD HARDLY BREATHE
I TAUGHT MYSELF THE LAND FROM THE BLUE RIDGE TO POCONOS
I BECAME AN EXPERT ON HOW TRAFFIC FLOWED
I LOVED MY LIFE ALONE
ON THE OPEN ROAD
AND THEN I MET THIS BOY AT A TRUCK STOP IN DES MOINES
HE WOULDN'T HITCH CAUSE HE HAD TOO MUCH PRIDE
SO I OFFERED HIM A RIDE
AND WE LEARNED EACH OTHER'S LAUGHS
AS WE TALKED ALL THROUGH THE NIGHT
AND WHEN HE THOUGHT THE TIME WAS RIGHT
HE KISSED ME IN THE CAR BENEATH A STARLESS SKY
AND WITH THAT KISS HE OPENED UP MY MIND
AND WE WENT DRIVING
WE WERE DRIVING
WE WERE DRIVING
JUST ME
A BEAUTIFUL BOY
AND THE OPEN ROAD

sp.speaker: SKIP
sp.p: Have you told your mom yet?

sp.speaker: SKIP
sp.p: (pause) Well... that's huge man, I'm really proud of you!

sp.speaker: WILL
sp.p: What? Oh. No, yeah that's awesome! I'm sorry... it's just... new.

sp.speaker: JACK
sp.p: Thanks. (beat) Is this going to be okay?

sp.speaker: JACK
sp.p: I just don't want anything to change. You guys are my best friends and that's absolutely the last thing I want.

sp.speaker: SKIP
sp.p: Well I don't know about you fellas, but I think this calls for a celebration! Everybody ready to get drunk?

sp.speaker: SKIP
sp.p: Great! Who's coming with me to the car?

sp.speaker: SKIP
sp.p: Of course. Always a step ahead, amigo!

sp.speaker: SKIP
sp.p: Sweet. (to WILL and ANDY) Back in a flash!

sp.speaker: WILL
sp.p: (to ANDY) Wow. (beat) Well... I wasn't expecting that.

body.stage: (Silence. ANDY is sitting on the player's bench staring at the ground)

sp.speaker: WILL
sp.p: (unconvinced) Yeah. I mean... of course I am...yeah.

lg.l: DON'T LOOK AT ME THAT WAY
I'M NOT CRAZY
THIS IS MY LIFE TOO
AND IT IS NOT A GAME
IF IT DOESN'T BOTHER YOU
THAT HE'S CHANGING, FINE
BUT WHEN I LOOK AT HIM
IT DOESN'T FEEL THE SAME
JACK IS GONE TO ME
I JUST WATCHED HIM DISAPPEAR
IT MAY BE WRONG TO LEAVE
BUT I DON'T WANT HIM HERE
WELL WHAT DO YOU WANT ME TO DO?
JUST DON'T GO
I KNOW IT'S NEW
BUT WHY SHOULD YOU HAVE TO LEAVE JUST CUZ HE'S OPENED UP
HE'S OUR BEST FRIEND, DON'T WE ASK THAT OF HIM?
IT'S BEEN A LONG TIME, IT'LL JUST TAKE SOME MORE
TO WORK IN OUR OLD WAY
OKAY?
NO
I WON'T SAY I DON'T CARE
I LOOK AND MY FRIEND ISNT THERE
I DON'T LIKE BEING LIED TO
OH, AND I DO?
WHEN THINGS GO WRONG
YOU ALWAYS SEE THE UPSIDE
WHY?
CAUSE I CAN STILL SEE HIM WHEN I LOOK AT HIS FACE
HE'S NOT ANY DIFFERENT, HE'S JUST IN A DIFFERENT PLACE
SO THINK ABOUT WHAT YOU SAY
CAUSE PEOPLE ARE ALLOWED TO CHANGE
WHY GREET THAT CHANGE BY CAUSING HIM PAIN?
I DON'T WANT TO HURT HIM
CAN'T YOU SEE THAT YOU WILL?
LOOK, THIS ISNT MY BURDEN
YOU'RE HIS FRIEND
YOU SHOULD TRY UNTIL YOU
UNDERSTAND HIM
MAYBE HE SHOULD
UNDERSTAND ME
THIS ISNT WRONG, ANDY THIS IS JUST NEW
YOU CANT WRITE OFF JACK CAUSE HE'S DIFFERENT THAN YOU
DONT MAKE IT SOUND
LIKE I'M THE ONE WHO'S WRONG
I WISH THINGS COULD STAY
THE WAY THEY WERE ALL
ALONG, BUT...
THINGS ARE DIFFERENT, WILL
THINGS HAVE CHANGED
JACK IS NO LONGER WITH US
ONLY THE SURFACE REMAINS
NOW ITS JUST YOU AND ME
AND SKIP. WE'LL WORK AS THREE
YOU'RE NOT
WRONG, BUT...
THIS ISN'T WRONG ANDY, THIS IS JUST NEW
HOW CAN YOU SAY THAT YOU CANT LOVE HIM
JACK NEVER SAID THAT YOU HAD TO LIVE
YOUR LIFE ONE WAY
LET GO OF YOUR BIAS, HE IS YOUR FRIEND
OR THIS COULD BE
NOT FOUR ANYMORE
WHAT ARE YOU ASKING ME TO DO?
LET IT GO
IS THIS FOR HIM OR FOR YOU?
JUST LET IT GO
WHY ARE YOU PUTTING THIS ON ME
LOOK, IM NOT SAYING I DISAGREE
BUT PLEASE, FOR ME, KEEP QUIET

body.stage: (ANDY walks up the bleachers, while WILL walks down the field. The distance between them should be significant. JACK and SKIP enter carrying two cases of Natty Light)
(JACK and ANDY don't laugh at this. The tension between them seems pretty obvious. JACK and SKIP set the cases on the player's bench.)

sp.speaker: SKIP
sp.p: Only the best for my boys! Natty Light!

body.stage: (SKIP tosses a can of Natty Light to WILL)

sp.speaker: WILL
sp.p: (sarcastic) Mmm... Did you steal these from your Dad's fridge?

sp.speaker: SKIP
sp.p: (recites the info from memory) Julio Mendez. 5225 Ridgemont Court. Ironwood, Minnesota. September 7th, 1983.

sp.speaker: WILL
sp.p: No it doesn't. This kid is Hispanic.

body.stage: (SKIP takes his ID away from WILL)

sp.speaker: JACK
sp.p: (grabbing a beer) You know, I didn't have a single drop of alcohol this past year, and wonder of wonders, I'm still sane.

sp.speaker: SKIP
sp.p: Yeah but you're gay. See what sobriety can do to you?

sp.speaker: SKIP
sp.p: No, that's for you. (noticing ANDY on the bleachers) Whatcha doing up there, champ? (offers ANDY a can) You want one?

sp.speaker: SKIP
sp.p: K. Catch? (ANDY doesn't respond) Fine, come get it yourself then. (beat) What's his deal?

body.stage: (SKIP sets the beer down on the player's bench. ANDY eventually walks down to get it.)

sp.speaker: WILL
sp.p: (WILL, covering, takes a sip.) This stuff is terrible!

sp.speaker: WILL
sp.p: Just saying, I thought you had better taste then this.

sp.speaker: SKIP
sp.p: Listen, I had ten dollars. For ten dollars, this is quality.

sp.speaker: JACK
sp.p: (to WILL) Did what's her face call?

sp.speaker: SKIP
sp.p: How long are we gonna to wait around for this girl?

sp.speaker: WILL
sp.p: I don't know. You got places to be?

sp.speaker: SKIP
sp.p: No, I just don't wanna be out here all night! That's all!

body.stage: (Silence. Will tries to cover the awkwardness again.)

sp.speaker: WILL
sp.p: (to JACK, about SKIP) So what do you think of this new look?

sp.speaker: JACK
sp.p: I wasn't gonna say anything but, you kinda look like a pothead.

sp.speaker: WILL
sp.p: I think he looks like a woman.

sp.speaker: SKIP
sp.p: You know what? I don't really care if it looks good or not.

sp.speaker: SKIP
sp.p: Why? Who am I trying to impress?

sp.speaker: JACK
sp.p: I have to admit, I'm a little surprised. I thought you were gonna come back looking like a total Ivy Leauge prep. You know, pink polo with the popped collar...

sp.speaker: SKIP
sp.p: Never! My roommate was like that. He wore plaid shorts every day of the week. It'd be 15 degrees outside and he'd still be wearing shorts and boat shoes. Dumbass.

sp.speaker: WILL
sp.p: Sounds like your kind of guy.

sp.speaker: SKIP
sp.p: Not to mention the fact that his dad bought him a Lexus when he graduated from high school.

sp.speaker: JACK
sp.p: Jesus. I got a check from my grandma that bounced.

sp.speaker: SKIP
sp.p: And the worst part about it is he thinks he's entitled to those things. Like he's owed something for doing nothing. Whatever. It's not worth wasting breath over.

sp.speaker: WILL
sp.p: Did that come with the hair too?

sp.speaker: WILL
sp.p: The "Whatever." You've said it like twenty times in the last two minutes.

sp.speaker: WILL
sp.p: I just expect more from you. This kid used to be your worst enemy and all you've got is "whatever"?

sp.speaker: SKIP
sp.p: What do you want me to say? He hasn't worked a day in his life and still he gets whatever he wants, and it sucks. But nothing I'm gonna do is gonna change that, so why get all upset over it?

sp.speaker: JACK
sp.p: ...When you can just grow your hair out.

sp.speaker: WILL
sp.p: Since when have you ever backed down from a character debate?

sp.speaker: SKIP
sp.p: Since I saw how pointless they are. Look, I can bitch and moan all I want about him... about anything... but ultimately it doesn't do shit. It's just one opinion.

sp.speaker: WILL
sp.p: What?! This coming from the most opinionated guy I know.

sp.speaker: JACK
sp.p: Think about all the shit he did. That was just one dude!

sp.speaker: SKIP
sp.p: Yeah, but Ghandi didn't live in an age of iPods and On Demand. People would rather sit on their asses and wait for someone else to do what they'd rather not do themselves, just because they can. My roommate isn't any different. So why should I be?

sp.speaker: WILL
sp.p: Because you are. You always have been. It's why we're friends.

sp.speaker: SKIP
sp.p: I thought we were friends because we sucked at football.

sp.speaker: SKIP
sp.p: (sarcastic) You mean changing the world and all that.

sp.speaker: SKIP
sp.p: Aww, Will, that's cute. But what are you actually doing to CHANGE it? Nothing. Talking on a football field. And that's what makes you just like all the rest of us.

lg.l: IN A WORLD THAT DEFINES ITSELF WITH X's Y2K's and Z's
YOU'RE PRESENT FOR A 3RD WORLD WAR
THATS REAL BUT YOU CHOOSE NOT TO SEE
YOU DON'T CARE OR EVER DARE OUTSIDE OF YOUR COMPLACENCY
CUZ IT'S NOT JUST YOU, THERE'S A NEW WORLD ORDER:
GENERATION APATHY

sp.speaker: SKIP
sp.p: Yes you are, you just don't notice.

lg.l: WE'RE ALL VIRGINS WHO ARE BURGEONING WITH READINESS FOR MORE
BUT WE'VE GOT PORNOS IN OUR DRAWERS
SO WE DON'T HAVE TO USE THE DOOR
WE FEED A NEED TO NEVER BLEED UNLESS WE'RE ABSOLUTELY SURE
WE GO THROUGH PAINSTAKING MEANS TO NEVER FEEL PAIN ANYMORE
WE USED TO BE YOUNG AND STUPID BUT NOW WE'RE JUST YOUNG
CAUSE WE DON'T ADMIT THE STUPID SHIT WE'VE DONE NOW THAT REAL LIFE HAS BEGUN
OUR GENERATION'S WAY OVERSEXED AND UNDERLOVED
AND UNDERWHELMED BY ALL OF THE ABOVE
WE COMPLAIN ABOUT OUR PERFECT LIVES WITH BIGGER WORDS THAN MOST
WE SPEW OUT FACTS AND FIND IT RELAXING TO TALK SHIT AS WE BOAST
ABOUT ME AND ME AND ME AND ME, LET'S ALL RAISE A TOAST
TO THE GENERATION THAT'LL TURN THIS NATION
FROM A SUPERPOWER INTO A GHOST
OUR FATHERS ARE COMMUTERS, BUT WE'RE STUCK IN OUR COMPUTERS
WHICH TAKE US ALL AWAY FROM ONE ANOTHER, BUT WHO CARES
CUZ WE'RE TOO OCCUPIED TO NOTICE WHAT WAS THERE HAS DIED
BETWEEN THE FAMILIES WHO USED TO LOVE EACH OTHER, CUZ WHO CARES
THE PROBLEMS OF THE WORLD WE'RE IN WILL ALWAYS BE RIGHT HERE
BUT RATHER THAN FIXING THEM WE'LL JUST JOIN IN WITH THE CHEER
WHO CARES
WHO CARES
WHO CARES WHO CARES WHO CARES
WHO CARES?
WE MAY GRADUATE WITH HONORS BUT THERE'S NO HONOR IN IT
WE ARE RUNNING A RACE BUT WE'RE OKAY IF WE DON'T WIN IT
WE ARE SMART BUT WE DON'T TRY - THE "DO I HAVE TO?" KIND OF GUY
WHO'LL NEVER RISK AND NEVER FAIL IF HE CAN SPIN IT
CHIVALRY AND BRAVERY AND THE QUALITIES WE USED TO BE
ARE NOW ONLY A MEMORY
AND WHAT I'M STILL WONDERING
IS WHAT'S THE MOST EXPENSIVE THING I CAN GET FOR FREE
I FEEL BAD BUT CAN'T HELP THE LAUGHTER
AT THE GENERATION THAT COMES AFTER
GENERATION APATHY

body.stage: (WILL pulls his phone out of his pocket and walk aways)

sp.speaker: WILL
sp.p: No, I just wanna know where she is.

body.stage: (WILL walks down the field, away from the guys and starts to call Patricia.)

sp.speaker: SKIP
sp.p: (to JACK and ANDY) Wow, he's being moody tonight.

body.stage: (WILL closes his phone and puts it back in his pocket)

lg.l: WHEN I FEEL ALONE, I HAVE THESE FRIENDS OF MINE
THE OTHER HALVES OF ME, WHO KEEP ME SANE IN TROUBLED TIMES
AND WHEN I LOSE MY WAY, I HAVE THEM THERE IN THE BACK OF MY MIND
AND THEN I DON'T FEEL LONELY AFTER ALL
WHEN I WAS YOUNG, I ONLY HAD MYSELF
TO GUIDE MY LIFELESS ACTION FIGURES TO THE FLOOR, DOWN FROM THE SHELF
MY BEDROOM WAS MY PLAYGROUND TO DRAW AND WRITE AND PRAY
THAT I WOULD FIND SOME REAL FRIENDS TO GUIDE ME SOMEDAY
AND NOW
WHEN I FEEL ALONE, I HAVE THESE FRIENDS OF MINE
THE OTHER HALVES OF ME, WHO KEEP ME SANE IN TROUBLED TIMES
AND WHEN I LOSE MY WAY, I HAVE THEM THERE IN THE BACK OF MY MIND
AND THEN I DON'T FEEL LONELY
WHEN I FEEL ALONE
THEY'VE ALL TURNED THEIR BACKS ON ALL THE THINGS WE SAID WE LOVED
CAUSE EVERYONE'S DECIDED THAT THIS ISNT WHAT IT WAS
WELL NOBODY ASKED ME IF I THOUGHT WE'RE ALLOWED TO CHANGE
MAYBE THAT'S BECAUSE IM THE ONE WHO'S STILL THE SAME
AND NOW
I AM STILL ALONE WITH ALL THESE FRIENDS OF MINE
THE OTHER HALVES OF ME WHO RAN AWAY IN TROUBLED TIMES
AND NOW I FEEL THE SHAME OF HOLDING ONTO WHAT'S NO LONGER MINE
MAYBE THINGS ARE DIFFERENT AFTER ALL
AND I JUST NEVER SAW IT AT ALL

body.stage: (SKIP notices WILL's notebook under the bench)

sp.speaker: SKIP
sp.p: (reads) "The Personal Memoirs of William Frances Levinson." Ooooh nooo...

body.stage: (He starts flipping through the pages of the notebook)

sp.speaker: SKIP
sp.p: (flipping through the pages of the notebook) Is this a diary?

sp.speaker: SKIP
sp.p: (reading) "The cabinet door had been left unlocked... big mistake."

sp.speaker: SKIP
sp.p: (smacking WILL's hand away as he reads) "I had been explicitly warned against going anywhere near my father's liquor. I knew the punishment would be severe, somewhere between grounding and death, but it was a risk I was willing to take -"

sp.speaker: WILL
sp.p: Look, could you not. It's private-

sp.speaker: SKIP
sp.p: Well then you won't mind if I read it. (reading) "I stared in awe at a row of glistening bottles on the top shelf, with names like Southern Comfort, Bristol Cream, and Wild Turkey. I chose the Comfort, and the boys dared me to take the first sip. " (to WILL) What is this?

sp.speaker: SKIP
sp.p: (flipping through the pages) There's a lot here.

sp.speaker: SKIP
sp.p: When did you write all this?

sp.speaker: ANDY
sp.p: Is that why you were in the room so much? I always thought you were just. you know... (mimes jerking off on a very small penis)

sp.speaker: JACK
sp.p:
(reading) "There was no real reason why we should have become friends. What tied us together was the fact that we were uncommon."
(Lighting shift w/ underscoring. This moment should be treated as an almost out of body experience.)
(reading) "Jack Moyer was incredibly small for his age and was constantly teased about it. During the first week of school, he had been targeted by a group of seniors who periodically stuffed him in one of the trashcans on the 2nd floor. By the time he'd get to eighth period he was covered in pencil shavings and smelled like chocolate milk."

sp.speaker: SKIP
sp.p: (reading) "Skip Thomas was a military brat who had lived in 5 different countries before the age of 14. His father was a high-ranking officer in the United States Army. He expected his children to call him sir and he called them men, before they even knew how to shave."

sp.speaker: JACK
sp.p: (reading) "When I first met Jack, he was wearing baggy sweatpants and a jersey that was almost twice his size, in what could only be construed as an attempt to compensate for his lack of... muscle mass?!"

sp.speaker: SKIP
sp.p: (reading) "At tryouts, Skip marched out from the locker room, complete with a GI Joe style crew cut, stopping only to stand at attention whenever a coach passed by."

sp.speaker: ANDY
sp.p: (reading) "Andy Scott lived on the corner of Woodmont and Great Oak Road with his three older brothers and younger sister."

body.stage: (ANDY punches SKIP in the arm and continues to read)

sp.speaker: ANDY
sp.p: "His father was a star quarterback for the OSU Buckeyes and his brothers had all played varsity football for the Beavers..."

sp.speaker: JACK
sp.p: (reading) "All I could think was that Jack bore a striking resemblance to ... Popeye??" What? "Without the pads he was a scrawny little runt, but when he put them on he instantly looked like he'd eaten his spinach."

sp.speaker: SKIP
sp.p: (reading) "Oh, and lest I forget the most important detail - Skip wasn't his real name either. We quickly called him that after he was introduced to us as..."

sp.speaker: JACK
sp.p: Come on, say it. Be proud.

sp.speaker: SKIP
sp.p: (biting) Hopper!! Hopper Fucking Thomas!! Like a stupid little bunny!!!

sp.speaker: JACK
sp.p: Yeah, your parents really weren't thinking long term with that one.

body.stage: (JACK and ANDY are both laughing at this)

sp.speaker: SKIP
sp.p: Screw you guys. I was named after my grandfather.

sp.speaker: JACK
sp.p: Why didn't they just name you Norman?

sp.speaker: SKIP
sp.p: I don't know. I wasn't there! Shut up!

sp.speaker: ANDY
sp.p: Let me read! (reading) "Andy seemed destined for athletic glory. Except for one minor problem. He was a terrible athlete. He failed at every sport he tried and his father and brothers never let him forget it. In an attempt to win their respect, Andy tried out for the JV football squad. But on the first day of tryouts Andy managed to run the ball into the wrong end zone. Twice."

sp.speaker: ANDY
sp.p: Whatever man! At least I touched the ball. You guys didn't even make it past wind sprints. (reading) "The seniors called him Conan, but I don't think Andy ever really understood why." (to WILL) What!? Yeah I did! It was cause I was strong as shit!

sp.speaker: ANDY
sp.p: Screw you! (reading) "When we left the field that day becoming friends seemed like a last resort.

body.p: But it actually resulted in an unexpected brotherhood. We knew we were different and as we spent more and more time together, we began to loath the idea of being 'normal.' We'd never be homecoming kings or football stars but in the grand scheme of things, that didn't matter. Our friendship was defined by who we were, by our standards. Life pushes you in a direction whether you choose it or not. Oddly enough, life turned us around so we could find each other."

sp.speaker: SKIP
sp.p: Come on Andy! We never would have become friends if you'd run those touchdowns into the right end zone. (beat) Either time.

sp.speaker: ANDY
sp.p: True, but it's a story, can't you change it a little? Artistic likeness?

sp.speaker: ANDY
sp.p: Yeah all that. Besides where's all the shit about you?

sp.speaker: ANDY
sp.p: Why isn't there anything in here about you being a fatty.

sp.speaker: ANDY
sp.p: Uh yes you were. You were a fucking tub! You were so fat your belly came out from under your jersey.

sp.speaker: WILL
sp.p: Whatever man, that was baby fat!

sp.speaker: ANDY
sp.p: Dude that was not baby fat. That was fat fat. You came to school with like twenty Snack Packs a day. You looked like Chunk from The Goonies!

body.stage: (The boys collapse and sprawl out on the grass.)

sp.speaker: WILL
sp.p: How many kids do you think have graduated from this place?

sp.speaker: WILL
sp.p: (WILL sits up) Seriously though, how many kids have filed in and out of this building over the years, like it was a goddamn assembly line. Think about all those kids that graduated in our class that we never even knew. Like, remember that skinny kid with the thick glasses who always farted in gym?

sp.speaker: WILL
sp.p: Yeah him! He'll forever be known as the kid you never wanted to follow behind during the rope climb. And that's probably all we'll ever know him as.

sp.speaker: ANDY
sp.p: He also borrowed my pen during Calculus and never gave it back. I'll never forget that.

sp.speaker: SKIP
sp.p: (to ANDY. Sarcastically amazed) You took Calculus?

sp.speaker: WILL
sp.p: (Will stands up and runs to the bleachers) I mean, how many kids do you think have sat out on these bleachers over the years? How many?(Will runs over to the bleachers and stands on the first row of seats) Who sat here? Huh? (Will runs back to the third row and stands) Who sat here? (The guys laugh. But WILL is driven.) No really! (beat) Think about how many people have made out right where you're sitting! (Points to where Andy is sitting)

sp.speaker: ANDY
sp.p: (reads some writing on the bleachers) Apparently "Chris and Amanda."

sp.speaker: WILL
sp.p: See, like that! Who are they? Where are they now? We could probably never figure out who they are. We'd have to go through every single yearbook...and even then there are probably thousands of Chris' and Amanda's.

sp.speaker: ANDY
sp.p: I bet Amanda's hot! Just saying.

sp.speaker: WILL
sp.p: Think about all the stuff that has happened out here. And we're part of it. Cuz we're really here.

sp.speaker: WILL
sp.p: No, I just have a vivid imagination.

sp.speaker: JACK
sp.p: Hey, do you guys remember when Will told us he was 16 when he wasn't?

body.stage: (Everyone explodes laughing, except for WILL of course)

sp.speaker: SKIP
sp.p: I haven't thought about that in so long.

sp.speaker: ANDY
sp.p: Yea, why did you lie about that? You knew we were gonna find out when we got our drivers' licenses.

sp.speaker: JACK
sp.p: You had me for a while though, I totally bought the "my mom wants me to wait until she thinks I'm ready."

sp.speaker: SKIP
sp.p: Cuz your mom would so do that. That bitch is crazy.

sp.speaker: SKIP
sp.p: Gentlemen, Andy Scott, case in point.

sp.speaker: ANDY
sp.p: Glad to be here, glad to be here.

sp.speaker: JACK
sp.p: I remember the day we caught you too. We were at Andy's house and your mom was like... (laughs) "It's gonna be so nice of you boys to drive Willy around until he TURNS 16." WHAAAAAAAAAT?

sp.speaker: WILL
sp.p: Listen jerks! Everything was going great, I didn't want the fact that we were different ages to mess anything up.

sp.speaker: ANDY
sp.p: It doesn't matter if our ages are symmetrical.

sp.speaker: ANDY
sp.p: No. I meant what I said.

sp.speaker: JACK
sp.p: You should be proud. You skipped Kindergarten! That means you're smarter than us.

sp.speaker: SKIP
sp.p: Yeah, who skips Kindergarten? Of all grades. "Oh, young William? He plays with blocks better than the other kids. Bump him!"

body.stage: (They all laugh. WILL's phone rings, Goofy ring.)

sp.speaker: WILL
sp.p: Screw you. (answers the phone) Hello!? Faa - Paa - Patty? Hey! Hi. So did you... Really!? (disappointed) Oh.

sp.speaker: WILL
sp.p: (into the phone) Don't worry about it. No no it's okay.

sp.speaker: WILL
sp.p: We'll figure something out. It'll be fine. Thanks anyway. (beat) Umm... yeah I'm actually busy Thursday night too so.... Uh-huh. Yeah that's a bad night too. Remember- broken bones. I got broken bones. Okay well gotta run, but I'll talk to you later. Okay. Great! Bye. (hangs up the phone) Jesus.

sp.speaker: WILL
sp.p: That girl does not give up.

sp.speaker: ANDY
sp.p: No, what's up with the key!?

sp.speaker: WILL
sp.p: Well... she says it's in the building.

sp.speaker: WILL
sp.p: Apparently it may be in the maintenance closet.

sp.speaker: JACK
sp.p: So what did she give us?

sp.speaker: WILL
sp.p: She doesn't know, but now she's pretty sure it's in there.

sp.speaker: ANDY
sp.p: (sarcastic) Well that's great, we probably have his car keys. What are we supposed to do now?

sp.speaker: SKIP
sp.p: (beat) You know... we could always try and sneak into the building?

sp.speaker: SKIP
sp.p: Well... there's that window in the gym. The one we used to sneak out of during assemblies. We could definitely get in through there. And if the closet's locked, screw it, let's just break in.

lg.l: AREN'T YOU READY FOR TONIGHT?
I'VE BEEN READY SINCE 5 YEARS AGO
TRESPASSING'S A CRIME, YOU KNOW
THEN WE'LL ABORT IF COPS SHOW

sp.speaker: ANDY
sp.p: I like where your head's at.

lg.l: I DUNNO...
ARE YOU SCARED NOW?
NO
I'LL GO WITH YOU
IF YOU SEE SOMEONE FIND SOMETHIN LOUD TO DO
NOW ARE YOU READY FOR READY FOR TONIGHT...

sp.speaker: ANDY
sp.p: All right. Let's fucking do this!

body.stage: (SKIP and ANDY exit, whooping and hollering. WILL and JACK are left alone.)

sp.speaker: JACK
sp.p: They're going to set off some alarm in that building and we're all gonna get caught.

sp.speaker: WILL
sp.p: No they wont! Jack, bad vibes!

sp.speaker: JACK
sp.p: Okay fine. Good vibes, good vibes. But you know I'm right.

body.p: So... is there a guy? Like a guy, like a boyfriend guy? Is that what you call it?

sp.speaker: JACK
sp.p: Sure. You can call it that.

sp.speaker: WILL
sp.p: The guy you met. You know, the one that you...

body.stage: (starts making weird gestures with his hands... he's not sure how to say it)

sp.speaker: WILL
sp.p: Yeah. Do you still talk to him?

sp.speaker: JACK
sp.p: I dunno. He lives in Iowa. I live here. It's not like I'm gonna start doing long distance. (beat) We're friends on Myspace, that's something, right?

sp.speaker: WILL
sp.p: (laughs) I guess. (beat) So, can I ask you a question?

sp.speaker: WILL
sp.p: Yea. How long have you known?

sp.speaker: WILL
sp.p: You know. I mean, was it something that you've always known or...

sp.speaker: WILL
sp.p: I dunno, I just - I've never gotten to ask anyone stuff like this before. And I just wanna know what it's like. I mean, what you're going through.

sp.speaker: JACK
sp.p: Well... I think part of me has always known... And I kind of just pushed it away. I'd think this isn't right. This isn't normal. And it stayed that way for a while. I just kept telling myself - I'll grow out of it. Eventually I'll meet some girl and everything will change. But it never did. So... (beat) it wasn't like a sudden realization or anything.

sp.speaker: JACK
sp.p: Cool. (beat) What do you think Andy thinks?

sp.speaker: WILL
sp.p: (caught off guard) I don't know... I'm not...

sp.speaker: JACK
sp.p: I'm just curious. I didn't know if he said anything to you when we left before.

sp.speaker: JACK
sp.p: I don't know. But he hasn't really said anything to me since -I just don't think he's thrilled.

sp.speaker: WILL
sp.p: Andy's weird. "What do you think Andy thinks?" is kind of a loaded question?

sp.speaker: JACK
sp.p: Yea. But I can tell when something's bothering him.

sp.speaker: WILL
sp.p: (beat) Well, I mean...okay. Okay, he did say something.

sp.speaker: JACK
sp.p: He did?? Why didn't you tell me?

sp.speaker: WILL
sp.p: Cuz he asked me not to. He didn't want to ruin the night. But I'd feel like a bad friend not telling you.

sp.speaker: WILL
sp.p: He just said he's not really all that cool with it, and you should have told us a while ago if you...were. Like you've been lying to us or blah blah blah. I dunno, it was pretty much bullshit.

sp.speaker: WILL
sp.p: NO! I mean it'd be better if you didn't, cause I told him I wouldn't tell you. So... I'm sorry... should I not have?

sp.speaker: JACK
sp.p: No you did the right thing. I just don't understand why he'd think that? Why would I try to screw things up?

sp.speaker: WILL
sp.p: It's not you, Jack. It's him.

body.stage: (JACK leans in and kisses WILL. WILL pulls away. Silence.)
(Silence. JACK leans in and kisses WILL again. ANDY and SKIP appear, having seen the second kiss.)
(JACK and WILL pull away from each other)

sp.speaker: WILL
sp.p: Andy, calm down. It was nothing.

body.stage: (ANDY grabs his jacket off the bleachers)

sp.speaker: WILL
sp.p: Andy, stop! We need to talk about this..

sp.speaker: ANDY
sp.p: (boiling.) Will. Do. You. Realize what you just did?!

sp.speaker: WILL
sp.p: You're right! I'm sorry. But it's not what you -

sp.speaker: JACK
sp.p: Andy, please, can we talk for a second?

sp.speaker: ANDY
sp.p: (to Jack) You came here tonight and dropped this shit on us and assumed that everything would be fine. It's NOT fine. You lied to us -

sp.speaker: SKIP
sp.p: Oh, Jesus, he didn't lie to you!

sp.speaker: JACK
sp.p: No, you lied to me too, Andy. Will told me what you said.

sp.speaker: JACK
sp.p: That you couldn't deal with it. That you've been sitting here all night and you didn't want to anything. Why not, why don't you just talk to me?

sp.speaker: ANDY
sp.p: (to WILL) Why would you tell him that....

sp.speaker: JACK
sp.p: He was being a good friend, Andy. I think I have the right to know that.

sp.speaker: SKIP
sp.p: Why is this bothering you so much?

sp.speaker: JACK
sp.p: I didn't tell you earlier, because I wasn't ready yet, Andy-

sp.speaker: ANDY
sp.p: Look, do whatever you want. I'm going.

sp.speaker: SKIP
sp.p: Why? What the fuck is your deal right now?

sp.speaker: WILL
sp.p: Everybody STOP IT! (to ANDY) You're right! I'm sorry. I'm sorry. Look its over. Just stay and we'll figure it out.(ANDY starts to leave) Andy, don't!

sp.speaker: JACK
sp.p: And now you have nothing to say? (beat) All right. I guess I'll leave.

sp.speaker: SKIP
sp.p: (to ANDY) What the hell is your problem?

sp.speaker: SKIP
sp.p: Why would you say that to him?

sp.speaker: SKIP
sp.p: Honestly, where is the disconnect in your brain! He's supposed to be one of your best friends and you treat him like he wronged you. He did nothing to you.

sp.speaker: SKIP
sp.p: You just fucked up a friendship for all of us because you're too selfish to get that it's not always about YOU!

sp.speaker: SKIP
sp.p: No! Everything that's coming out of your mouth tonight is toxic, and I'm tired of listening to it.

sp.speaker: ANDY
sp.p: No! (to SKIP) It's not about him being gay, Skip, it's about -

sp.speaker: SKIP
sp.p: I don't wanna hear it! No one does -

sp.speaker: WILL
sp.p: Andy, please just be quiet. You're making it worse.

body.stage: (WILL, near tears, is on the ground, trying to piece together his journal)
body.p: What was he talking about? You lied to him?

sp.speaker: WILL
sp.p: No. (beat) I lied to him. And Jack. And you.

sp.speaker: WILL
sp.p: Andy told me he wasn't cool with Jack coming out and I told him not to saying anything, cause I didn't want anything to get fucked up. But I fucked it up anyway. (beat) This is all my fault.

sp.speaker: SKIP
sp.p: Oh calm down. The world's not ending. They'll cool off. Maybe they'll even make out, everyone else is doing it. (beat) Why were you guys kissing anyways? Something you wanna tell me?

sp.speaker: WILL
sp.p: No. I dunno. He kissed me. I just - let it happen.

sp.speaker: SKIP
sp.p: You can't go around trying to please everyone Will.

body.stage: (WILL continues to pick up the pieces of the notebook)

sp.speaker: SKIP
sp.p: (beat) It's just a diary. You can always get another one.

sp.speaker: WILL
sp.p: (smiles) It's not a diary. (beat) Skip...everything I've ever felt was in this thing.

sp.speaker: SKIP
sp.p: Maybe not. (holding the papers in his hand) This stuff was from when we were kids, Will. We've grown up a little since then.

sp.speaker: WILL
sp.p: I know, but when the hell did that happen?

WE HAD FUN

AND EVEN ONE
WITH GOOD INTENT HAS POWER TO RUIN

I DON'T LIKE THIS FEELING
THAT I COULD BE LOSING YOU
NOBODY IS LOSING
EVERYONE'S JUST GROWING TOO
WHAT IF THIS WAS NEVER RIGHT
AND IT TOOK US UP UNTIL TONIGHT
TO REALIZE WE'D BEEN SAVING FACE
AND ADMIT WE ARE OUT OF PLACE
DON'T FIGHT TO FIGURE OUT
SOMETHING WE'LL ALL JUST LAUGH ABOUT
ONE DAY
ONE DAY
I AM NOT READY TO STOP BEING A KID
WELL NOBODY SAID THAT WAS WHAT YOU NEEDED
WE'LL NEVER BE WHO WE WERE BEFORE
BUT NEVER SAY THAT WE'RE NOT BOYS...
ANYMORE
ANYMORE
ANYMORE

sp.speaker: SKIP
sp.p: God I hate this place. Why couldn't we have gone to Andy's and watched Ella Enchanted? (beat) I'm gonna go. You want a ride?

sp.speaker: WILL
sp.p: Yeah...I think I'm gonna stay out here a little longer.

sp.speaker: SKIP
sp.p: All right. We're gonna be okay. I promise.

body.stage: (SKIP pulls a key out of his pocket and tosses it to WILL)

sp.speaker: SKIP
sp.p: Yeah, the closet was unlocked. So... you went on that date for no reason. Just saying.

sp.speaker: WILL
sp.p: I know. I love you too.

lg.l: LOOK AT THIS FIELD
LOOK AT THIS PERFECT FIELD
WHAT REALLY KEEPS PEOPLE HERE?
THESE WHITE LINES?
NO BOUNDARIES TO HOLD US HERE
EXCEPT FOR MINE
IT MIGHT BE TIME TO TRY AND FIND A DIFFERENT KIND OF STORY
INSTEAD OF ONE THAT IVE BEGUN BUT CANT SEEM TO COMPLETE
CEPT THIS IS ALL I KNOW AND I DON'T KNOW WHERE ELSE TO GO
OR WHAT ELSE THERE IS TO ME
IF THEY'RE NOT GONNA BE IN MY NEXT STORY
THEY SAY TO WRITE THE THINGS YOU KNOW
WELL THAT I HAVE, AND THERE THEY BLOW
AROUND THIS FIELD, NO WAY TO SEW
THEM BACK TOGETHER
I WANT TO SAY IM SORRY FOR
MY INDISCRETIONS FROM BEFORE
BUT NO ONE'S HERE TO HEAR ANYMORE
AND BRING US BACK TOGETHER
I DIDN'T WANT TO GET IT
WHEN SHIFTING STARTED TO OCCUR
I DIDN'T WANT TO LET IT
MAKE US WHO WE ARE FROM WHO WE WERE
BUT THERE REALLY WOULD BE SOMETHING GOOD IF I COULD WRITE A STORY
WITH NO CONVERSIONS OF VERSIONS OF MYSELF I HATE TO BE
AND THIS DRAFT THAT I DO WOULD BE COMPLETELY TRUE
WHICH SEEMS QUITE OVERDUE FOR ME
BUT THAT DOESN'T MEAN I SEE MY NEXT STORY
LETS SEE

WHEN AM I GROWN UP AND WHEN AM I STILL IMMATURE?
WILL I EVER BE MORE THAN JUST UNSURE?
AND WHEN AM I MAN?

WHEN I WAS THE GLUE THAT HELD US TOGETHER
OBSERVOR, INVENTOR, AND SOLE DOCUMENTOR
CONSTANTLY WATCHING, THE CONSTANT INCENTIVE
TO KEEP MOVING FORWARD, AND ALWAYS...
REMEMBER...

THAT TAKES ACCOUNT OF THE AMOUNT OF LIFE I'VE YET TO SEE

AND THIS IS WHAT I SEE
RIGHT HERE IN MY STORY

body.stage: (The sprinkler system goes off, soaking WILL.)
